title: Speed
description: Los Angeles SWAT cop Jack Traven is up against bomb expert Howard Payne, who's after major ransom money. First it's a rigged elevator in a very tall building. Then it's a rigged bus--if it slows, it will blow, bad enough any day, but a nightmare in LA traffic. And that's still not the end.

reviews.text: Speed is one of the most underrated thrillers ever. Reeves, Hopper, Bullock and Daniels give brilliantperformances. There is also enough pumping suspense for any film buff. Every second of the movieis classic and intriguing, A+.

This is an unmitigated masterclass in holding the audience within an uncomfortable, yet thrilling zone of tension and uncertainty, constantly giving the protagonistic forces roadblocks upon roadblocks to try and problem-solve. Things go from bad, to worse, to even worse, to "oh, dear God, why?" at such an alarming rate and it is nothing short of an absolute blast to watch from start to finish. Jan De Bont's "Speed" is up there with "Die Hard" and "Lethal Weapon" -- that is to say, it's one of the finest, pure action movies ever conceived, produced, and witnessed.

An awesome, terrific popcorn thriller and a pure adrenaline rush. Speed is definitely one hell of a ride, and the greatest ride of a lifetime. It's fast paced, mysterious and suspenseful, full of nonstop action and adventure, tense, taut and energetic, leaving you fastening your seat belt tight and hanging on to your seats (literally!) from start to finish. The movie is divided into three sections, the falling express elevator with 13 business executives, then a Santa Monica city bus with 19 passengers and finally, a subway train with only three people, the hero, villain and victim. Director Jan de Bont uses every form of transportation and has Dennis Hopper rig it with explosives, pushing its velocity to its maximum limits. First, you speed up an elevator, then you speed up a city bus over 50 MPH and you have to keep it moving across the downtown city streets and rush hour traffic. The bus literally speeds through LA, swerves, accelerates, jumps and flies! (Like the Magic School Bus) before finally ending up at LAX circling the runway. The bus scene lasts over 50 minutes and becomes the main highlight of the movie, similar to how de Bont substantially expands on Annie's character as she rises in rank from an ordinary bus passenger to Jack's sidekick and love interest. The action, thrill and excitement never stops even when the boobytrapped bus is out of the picture. When the subway train accelerates to full speed and derail on the street, because it goes much faster than a bus. Overall, this is one of the best action film I've seen since the summer of 1994, making it true summer fun. It's the pure definition of an action film.

If you're looking for action movie heaven, try Speed, a crackling blend of suspense and fun that gives you the rush of a runaway roller coaster. It's morning-drive time in Los Angeles as a bus packed with passengers heads for the freeway. In a hide-out filled with surveillance gadgetry, mad bomber Howard Payne (Dennis Hopper going full-tilt bug **** as only he can) phones SWAT cop Jack Traven (Keanu Reeves) with a perverse pop quiz: "There's a bomb on the bus. Once the bus goes 50 miles per hour, the bomb is armed. If it drops below 50, the bus blows up. Whaddya do, Jack?" What the bomber wants to do is get Jack to fork over $3.7 million. But Jack is a bit of a loose cannon himself — his partner, Harry (Jeff Daniels), describes him as "deeply nuts." What Jack wants to do is hop on the bus, disarm the bomb, then find this psycho and whup his extortionist ass. Guess who gets his wish? Hollywood cynics have tagged Speed as Die Hard on a bus. Fair enough. Originality isn't the film's strong suit; execution is. Under Siege was prematurely dissed as Die Hard on a submarine until Andrew Davis showed what a gifted director could do with a formula plot. First-time director Jan De Bont performs similar marvels with Speed. De Bont, the acclaimed cinematographer who took his camera under the ocean in The Hunt for Red October and up Sharon Stone's skirt in Basic Instinct, also shot the original Die Hard. He's learned firsthand how to grab an audience. And though the script by newcomer Graham Yost lacks the solid character base of last summer's Fugitive and In the Line of Fire, the acting is as kinetic as the action. Reeves is a major surprise; he cuts a sturdy figure far removed from the malebimbo act that made him a star in Bill and Ted's Excellent Adventure and proved ruinous to his so-called serious performances in Dracula and Much Ado About Nothing. Reeves' hard of body/soft of head image gets tweaked in Speed when the bomber tells Jack: "Don't attempt to grow a brain." But Reeves has the last laugh by delivering a vigorous, no-bull performance that suggests we'll be able to hear his name in the future without silently mouthing the word dude. While Reeves and Hopper play a battle of wits, Sandra Bullock nearly drives off with the picture. As Annie, a passenger whom Jack puts behind the wheel when the bus driver is shot, the smart and sassy Bullock is a knockout. She makes us believe the impossible things Annie is doing and, better, makes us care. Bullock's roles in Demolition Man, Wrestling Ernest Hemingway and The Thing Called Love would have made her a star already if the films were less dreary. Speed is a spiffier vehicle, and it's a pleasure to watch her ride this baby home. Jack picks Annie to drive because she's had her license revoked for speeding. She's more exhilarated than scared keeping the bus hurtling along even when it means flooring the gas pedal to clear a 50-foot gap in the freeway or taking a detour into city traffic that becomes a nerve-rattling demolition derby. The stunts, including Jack's leaping onto the bus from a moving car and his trying to dismantle the bomb while dangling near wheels that could squish him into road kill, will have you ducking in your seat. If the bus doesn't get you, there's the elevator crash that opens the film and the subway chase that closes it. Still, the fireworks wouldn't count for much if the hardware overwhelmed the humanity. Speed cinches its spot as the thrill ride of summer by providing characters to hiss at and root for. Jack and Annie actually manage to strike up a convincing romance even at hyperspeed and without taking their eyes off the road. It's an impressive feat enhanced by the film's knack — shared with The Fugitive — for serving up two hours of pure pow without gratuitous gore. Action flicks are usually written off as a debased genre, unless, of course, they work. And Speed works like a charm. It's a reminder of how much movie escapism can still stir us when it's dished out with this kind of dazzle. Pass the popcorn.

Great, thrilling film. I remember it being very tense bolstered with great acting by each character. Every character here felt like they belonged here. Keanu Reeves really did take advantage of the lead role in this one. The story was also written very well. Considered a classic, and I don't see why not, I'm not sure I have any friends that haven't see this piece!

Speed is an awesome thriller with great sequences and satisfying characters. The premise of this movie is simple yet super interesting. The characters are like able and the antagonist is menacing. The casting of the movie is also great, as well as the direction, camera work, and writing. Would recommend to anyone looking for a good thriller.

Director Jan de Bont’s action-movie “Speed” is nothing besides an outstanding film that tells the story of characters trapped in a bus being driven by Annie Porter (Sandra Bullock) while a cop called Jack Traven (Keanu Reeves), is tryng to disarm a bomb in the vehicle. One of the greatest points of the movie are it’s characters, wich, even tought being both extremely charismatic and skilled, on the end of the day are just common people trying to outcome an uncommon situation. The characters decisions and attitudes are generally understandable and believable, even tought their respective arcs somehow manage to be gripping, on their own ways. Bont also delivers a truly impressive artwork with the action scenes, leaving the spectator on the edge of his seat the whole movie and provoking a lot of anxiety.The big selling point of the movie, although, isn’t the villain, Howard Payne (Dennis Hopper), wich shows a giantic lack of charisma. The movie’s antagonist simply can’t convince anyone with his motivations either, he is an ex-officer that is revolted by the fact that, even dedicating years to the Police Department, didn’t get rich.There isn’t any word that can describe this incredible masterpiece better than “breathtaking”. The story, the casting selection, and the feelings that the spectators will experience during the filme, are just mesmerizing.
Una película llena de acción y emoción, con buenas actuaciones y escenas increíbles.

Brilliant story, fast paced action and incredible performances from Bullock, Reeves and Hopper. Speed is a bulls-eye of an action movie that will take your breath away.

Speed is by no means visionary, but it is a very well constructed, and tense action film.  It's entertaining pretty much the whole way through, which really isn't as common an aspect with action movies as you'd think it would be.  The film was more exciting and had more surprises than I expected it would, so I'm giving it a high recommendation for anyone looking for a well oiled thrill ride.  There is one problem however that I couldn't ignore.  Keanu Reeves gives a wooden and extremely unconvincing performance.  I'd expect that from him, but he's still shockingly un-nuanced in his role here.  He was way better in the Matrix.  Other than that, Speed is a fast paced and extremely fun movie.
the best of the "speed" movies. Sandra Bullock was hot and so was Keanu Reeves' acting.

This could be the most overrated film I have ever seen. People make it out to be a classic, personally I don't see it.  That is not to say it's a bad film, because it isn't bad, it's just not very good. There is little to no tension in most of the scenes, and I was really excited going into to this, having read the rave reviews, but I was disappointed.
Speed kills.A very entertaining action film with a simple plot and little to no character development. In this case, story wasn't needed all that much as suspense was the formula for its substance.

Après l'immeuble, l'aéroport, le train, le bateau... (et quoi d'autre encore ? j'en oublie sûrement) voici Die Hard dans le bus et en dessous aussi. Le prochain, ils le feront dans une cabine téléphonique... quoique, je crois que ç'a déjà été fait... en fait. Alors, pourquoi pas dans un frigidaire ?Quoi qu'il en soit, le machin est bouclé en moins d'une heure et demi, ce qui s'avère très bénéfique en terme d'action (évidemment) mais aussi de rythme : ici, c'est mené tambour battant et Keanu ne balance aucune joke (sauf à la toute fin mais ça tombe à plat...) et il reste en outre toujours habillé correctement au contraire de l'autre tanche au débardeur crado qui devrait faire la pub pour Ariel.Le cabotin, c'est ce bon vieux Dennis Hooper qui s'y connaît en crevard très vindicatif et il le fait très bien, presque avec sobriété ma foi... La cocotte Bullock est légèrement hystérique cependant mais rien de méchant. Et Keanu est sérieux.Malgré le poids des ans (1994 quand même) Speed est resté spectaculaire et on en a pour son argent. Dommage que la réalisation soit un brin perfectible : la caméra a le mal de mer et c'est trop souvent zoomé exagérément. Mais à côté des Bay, Liman, Greengrass et cons(pagnie) et autres trouducs du cinéma moderne, on dirait du Kubrick.Assez divertissant donc, clairement efficace mais un peu juste tout de même, ce Speed.

Speed is a 1994 action, adventure, thriller that also has some elements of romance but it's not classed as a romance film... It has plenty of action but Speed is basically about a terrorist (Dennis Hopper) who after blowing a lift and the innocents escape due to help from the police and LAPD then makes the cops believe he is dead after he detonates a bomb strapped to him. Later on he rigs a city bus and Jack Traven (Keanu Reeves) has to board the bus and keep it's speed above 50 because if the bus speed drops below 50mph it explodes thereby killing everyone on board.. Jeff Daniels and Joe Morton also star along with Sandra Bullock...I wouldn't say Speed is the best film ever made but it's up there and it's a worthy competitor and it wouldn't have worked if Keanu Reeves and Dennis Hopper didn't get involved. Good film (contains bad language and violence)
This movie gets down to business right away. After the first disarnament, it's a non-stop battle to keep the bus at speed, and the thrills never stop until Dennis Hopper finally bites the dust.
Great film, love watching it. Just a well made movie.
On the one side great action, nonstop adrenaline, top stunts and effects.BUT: the story has so many logical mistakes. So it is another entertaining movie for the masses.

Awesome thriller, thanks to the stunning performances of Keanu Reeves, Sandra Bullock and Dennis Hopper, energetic direction from Jan de Bont, and a script original enough to carry the movie. Final Score: 8/10

One of the best thrillers of its time. It is an intense cat and mouse game with an excellent cast that is entertaining from start to finish. Sadly the sequel killed the franchise and there is not much talking about the movie anymore. The movie is about a confrontation between SWAT officers and an extortionist bomber. The bomber is a clever schemer that seems always one or two steps ahead. This creates an intense experience that grabbed me from the beginning. There is always a Damocles sword above the heads of the protagonist. Sadly I cant go into details to avoid spoilers. Lets say the story, twists and characters are excellent. The main actors with Keanu Reeves, Sandra Bullock, Jeff Daniels and Dennis Hopper fully deliver their roles. They have a great chemistry and work well. I cant imagine anyone better suited for this movie. I have also to praise the team behind the camera, director and writer. Those are the other half of a really good movie (One does not work well without the other). Other than that the stunts, explosions and drive scenes are fully conniving and add to the intense atmosphere. I think I already summed up everything necessary. Overall this movie was a great success making approx 10 times its production cost and was talked a lot back then. I would recommend this movie if you like an adrenaline ride. Sadly it never became a cult movie as it is a bit forgotten but also when you mention it well remembered.
Till date there has been no film that has given the nail buting experience that this film has given.

I say see this film as it is my favorite film of the 1990s. I'm not gonna give out any spoilers. So you have to see this movie to know why I think it's a great film.
Speed is a classic example of popcorn action movie, with a tight plot, fast-paced progression, non-stoping thrills, and Keanu Reeves and Sandra Bullock constantly exuding hormones

a typical 90s action film...but somehow more too ... at least the chemistry between the main actors is interesting or why the bus lets the gravity fly while flying in the air and bumps up front...but we don't want to be too specific.

A classic 90s action movie...This is a movie I can watch over and over again and NEVER get bored of it. The story seems so simple when you look at it from the outsiders perpective...A bomb has been fitted onto a public bus, if the bus drops below a certain speed limit, the bus will explode...but what comes out of this is just jaw dropping in terms of action and suspense. Right until the credits roll you are on the edge of your seat. HIGHLY RECCOMMENDED.

I've seen very few films that have a more exciting and ridiculously suspenseful plot than Speed. The adventure is endless, the filming is impeccable, and the acting is more than impressive, resulting in a jaw-dropping action blockbuster that deserves it's place among Keanu Reeve's best films throughout the many years of his acting career. In all truth and honesty, Speed is considerably underrated among the general audience, nonetheless, I do believe it will only become increasingly popular and appreciated as the years pass by. As CGI and special effect uses become more frequent in the 21st century, Speed will simply bring viewers back to a past of raw and brilliant filmmaking, and an era of masterful movie directing.
Super-exciting film! The action scenes, special effects, and acting by Sandra Bullock, Keanu Reeves, and Dennis Hopper are fantastic! Certain people do not like this movie, but it is a blast!
Little bit overrated but at the time this movie must have been goated. Doesn't hold up too well imo but still good watch
